Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2012 04:48AM PizzaDad wrote: My wfe gets those alternative treament suggestions from people all the time.  I do the due dilligence and research it on the internet.  Some of the "alternative treatments" are no different than the regimen her doctor has had her on.  Some are chicanery.  Often people see a 1 minute blurb on a morning news show about a cancer treatment and tell my wife she has to get on it because it's the cure......it will turn out to be some study that shows promise in lab mice.....years and years away from applicaton to humans, if ever at all.  I try not to get bitter toward the people who send those things.  Most people just don't understand how complex cancer treatment is and think one type of cancer is all that there is.  We have achieved an increased awareness of breast cancer but that doesn't always equate to increased understanding.  I certainly can't fault anyone for wanting to try to get better.  Heck, my wife's cancer has progressed without pause thru 6 chemo's and her Onc suggested that perhaps it wouild be better to just cease treatment and not have the side effects in these last few months. But she said give me another treatment and we are doing Halaven.
Posts.Title: alternative treatments soleil505 Lemonsoda

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2011 08:03PM PizzaDad wrote: Sounds wonderful.  Congratulations.
Posts.Title: Oh, I almost forgot.... cookie97 apple

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2011 07:11PM PizzaDad wrote: Glad you got that wonderful news.
Posts.Title: Just got a call IwillBhealed vickib

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 07:27PM PizzaDad wrote: What about for the male BC survivors out there?  I love MOOBs?
Posts.Title: Since we all love a good rant Fitztwins WingsofHope

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2012 05:29AM PizzaDad wrote: Thank you all so much.  I appreciate the words of wisdom and the prayers and well wishes.  And I appreciate just having some outlet to talk about what is happening and not have people give me that blank stare because they don't know what to say, can't relate and are afraid they will say something wrong.  We have not talked to our boys yet.  We were planning for today but Elka wants to wait. My older son turns 16 Tuesday.  My wife doesnt' like the idea of telling him this so close to his birthday.  Maybe we will delay it till Wednesday.  I'm starting to lean that way.  Just let the Birthday come and pass without this knowledge.  We have met with her first husband (my 16 year old's father) and told him. Probably a situation some others here have worried about.  What happens to the children in a blended family in the event of death.  As a father I understand why he will want his son living with him but am worried about losing touch with the boy I raised and love and worried about his sense of the world being shattered and being torn from the home he has been raised in and being seperated from his brother.  I have promised Elka that I will do everything I can to make sure that this family continues to be a family.
Posts.Title: My baby got a time stamp. PizzaDad Naniam

Posts.Content: PizzaDad wrote: Following some good advice from folks on this board, I took my wife to see one of her Nurses.  She has several nurses who work with her doctor but I asked specifically for the one I feel is take charge and super efficient.  When the nurse heard that Elka had been nauseas for several days and was hard to wake up after she slept she agreed that she should be scanned.  She consulted with one of the doctors in the office for the needed approvals and came back with the offer of inpatient or outpatient.  I stuck my big nose in it and said we weren't going home till we found out what was what.  She was admitted,xrayed, scanned, and evaluated over the next 24 hours.  Her lungs are trashed.  There is not enough fluid to drain.  Her breathing problems are due to progression of the cancer.  After speaking with both the pulmonologist and her Onc, we had to evaluate the options and ultimately she had to make a choice.   The Onc doesn't have a realistic expectation of the chemo doing anything to slow down the cancer.  I like this lady because she is honest. The facts are, at the stage my wife currently is, continued treatment could hasten her demise.  The two chemo regimens she had in mind, Halevan and navelbine, are both likely to cause SE that will tear my wife down more...she also stated that just because the previous 5 didn't work doesn't mean one of these won't.   Decision time.  Accept it, and stop Chemo to maximize what time is left or fight some more.   Elke asked how much time we were talking about..  The Onc said she can't really say but she can give her a guess based on her experience.....Months!   How many? Elka heard Two....I corrected her later, it was "a few" We talked and cried about it that night and in the morning when the Onc came she said "I can't stop.....it feels like just giving up".    So she is going to try Halaven so long as she can tolerate it. She also told the Doc to get her out of the hospital because we had dinner reservations tonight. The meds they pumped into her did a tremendous job....as did doubling her oxygen from 2 liters to 4 liters.   We went to a fondue resturaunt with close friends.  It was great.  Good food, and good conversation with both our families for 3 1/2 hours.  Only thing that wasn't great was the stink of cooked meat that stuck to all of our clothes afterwards.    So here we are. Next week we start our Hail Mary pass with Halaven. We are trying to buck the system and thumb our nose at this timestamp.  I know that nobody really has one and it isn't time till it's time but she needed to know what she was looking at.  We have some tough conversations to hold with the kids.   Husband of Stage IV BC patient. Triple Neg stage II discovered summer of 2007. Surgery, Chemo, Radiation. We thought we were in the clear until Jan 2011. Mets to Lungs, bone and liver. Currently taking Halaven Dx 1/31/2011, Stage IV, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2011 05:48PM PizzaDad wrote: Merry Christmas.  Stable sounds lke a wonderful thing to hear.
Posts.Title: Stable for Christmas DivineMrsM GatorGal

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2012 10:00PM - edited Apr 21, 2012 10:01PM by PizzaDad No way.  I am the husband of a survivor/fighter, and the son of a breast cancer casualty and the grandson of a lung cancer casualty and I can assure you, that every time I hear a good story of a woman or man who twists and turns and writhes their way out of the jaws of that hideous beast I feel like a soccer hooligan who's team has just won the cup.  Feel sorrow for the fallen and their families but don't give in to guilt.  By luck and by courage, you are still here.  Keep fighting,, please.....every time I read about one of you ladies who is still giving cancer the finger and living another good day I feel like I just met one of my childhood heroes. You absolutely deserve this time.
Posts.Title: Survivor guilt... llanabeth GatorGal

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2011 05:52PM PizzaDad wrote: Hooray.  Great to hear such encouraging news.  Can't wait till the researchers are able to button all this information about positive results together and come up with a true solution.

Posts.Title: I am a NERD Mazy1959 Mazy1959

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 09:10PM PizzaDad wrote: I'm the husband of a breast cancer patient. Stage 4.  If I had it to do over, I would beg my wife to get a BMX.  Take everything associated with her breast the first time they detected anything.  Would it have made a difference?  I have no idea.  The cancer may have already spread beyond the breast tissue. Hind sight is twenty twenty.  Current medical philosophy says I'm wrong but when I mentioned it to my wife she said she felt the same way.  I absolutely love my wife.  Fake boobs or no boobs would have suited me just fine.  Losing her does not. When they told her she could just do a lumpectamy instead of BMX I think part of the decision process was made in a state of emotional numbness and part of it was autopilot because we have constantly been bombarded with newsette reporting that talks about how breast cancer treatment no longer requires the loss of a breast.  the way it is reported it almost seems to say You shouldn't allow them to take the breast. The decision has to be made so quickly that it is really hard to weigh it properly.  I don't know what th answer should be.  But I wish we had taken extreme action and not just the partial mastectamy.    I debated on answering you because you and you alone can make the decision on what you should do and my situation is extreme and prejudicial.  Whatever decision you make, I pray you live to be 100 years old.
Posts.Title: How do you decide? keepnfaith bdavis

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 07:34AM PizzaDad wrote: My bride has lung mets.  Currently she is on Taxotere but I am going to be asking about halaven and navalbine today when we go in for her appointment.  She has had fluid in her lungs and a terrible time breathing the last few weeks.I'm hoping one of the others will be a bit kinder to her. Hope you have good success on the navalbine.
Posts.Title: mets to lung bhd1 movingsoccermom

Posts.Content: PizzaDad wrote: This is the first treatment she has missed.  We did the 9 session of carbo/gemzar then switched to Abraxane.  This would have been the 3rd treatment of the second cycle.  Last week she felt like shiza but her white cound was up over 5....highest it has been since we found out she had cancer again.  She has been having lots of coughing ever since Christmas and was being treated for that.  I figured it was the meds that were bringing her white count up.  We went to the shore for Memorial day weekend and she was feeling pretty good today when she went in,, but we were quite surprised to be told she couldn't get her chemo. She is devestated.  Scared.  She has been feeling like maybe it wasn't working and now she doesn't get her treatment so she is running all kinds of negative thoughts thru her head.  I am little use, tellingl her not to let this get her too freaked out.  I am thinking this is not too uncommon and we will get her healed up and back in the swing of treatment.   Husband of Stage IV BC patient. Triple Neg stage II discovered summer of 2007. Surgery, Chemo, Radiation. We thought we were in the clear until Jan 2011. Mets to Lungs, bone and liver. Posts.Content: PizzaDad wrote: My wife has been on Carboplatin/Gemzar for 9 weeks.  Scans this week showed pretty much no change.  Her lungs had "innumerable" nodes to start and still do. some have gotten smaller, some bigger.  Bone met is unchanged.  Her ONC is switching her to Abraxane.  It was a bittersweet bit of news.  No progression in the disease is good news but we were hoping for improvement.  I have read good things on here about Abraxane.  Off we go. Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 10:49AM PizzaDad wrote:  My wife has a pair of Ugg boots that she has been wearing for 4 years.  Each year she orders a new footbed from the company and says it makes it feel like a new pair of boots.  This year when we got back from vacation she said she was looking at a new pair of boots "but I'm not sure I'm gonna be here next winter so I don't want to waste money."  I asked what color are the boots?  She said brown I said buy them.  "You have tan boots that go with lots of stuff, the brown will be something you can wear  with different clothes.  Besides, it's cold right now, not.  Worry about next year when it gets here."    Glad you got the coat.
Posts.Title: Should I Buy a Winter Coat? eag1954 eag1954

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2012 09:41PM PizzaDad wrote: The tears come when I least expect it.  I havn't seen my wife cry since her last hospital stay and even then I think she was crying over worry for me and the kids.....I hope she is just hiding her tears from me instead of not having them.  I'm pretty sure she is having them just doesn't want to cry in front of me.  That bothers me but I guess it shouldn't because I don't want to cry in front of her.  I don't want the make her upset.  I usually cry in the car.  Only for a few seconds then I can suck it up but it's a really good manic sob for those few seconds.  I wish I had something to say to bring some solace for you but I really don't.  But I think I understand crying even if my perspective isn't the same.
Posts.Title: crying tonite apple banjobanjo

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 10:17PM PizzaDad wrote: Thank you, everyone.  I don't have to tell you how helpful it is to just feel like the people you talk to are capable of understanding you.  I guess I should put something under a signature line to tell what we are dealing with.  It's TN Bone and Lung. having less treatment options sure sucks.Althought this sucks for anyone.  I'm gratefull to god for not making it worse
Posts.Title: Is the Chemo strong enough? PizzaDad PizzaDad

Posts.Content: PizzaDad wrote: First round of breast cancer was stage two in 2007.  Almost 3 years to the day from her last Chemo, DXed with stage IV.  One bone Met to collarbone, and innumerable lung mets.  They set her up for Carbo/Gem cocktail and she was supposed to go into the Parp trial till that got cancelled.  Started her first chemo on Valentines day.  2 weeks on, one off.  It's only been 2 weeks but she is questioning if it's strong enough because she doesn't feel as bad as she expected to feel.  She gets her Chemo on Monday,, feels ok, eats a decent meal that night, Tuesday a little tired but still ok. Wednesday she comes home from work and sleeps for several hours.  She will probably do the same thing tonight, and maybe tomorrow.  Saturday she was feeling fine and Sunday she barely had any fatigue at all.  Her regimen is 2 weeks on and one week off (to let her body regroup I think.)   Her concern is that she is handling it fairly well except for constipation and maybe that means it isn't a strong enough treatment.  I've seen mention on this board of several women who didn't tolerate it well so I have no answers but it seems like the SE are a case by case thing.   What do I tell her when she says she expected to feel worse, besides be glad? Husband of Stage IV BC patient. Triple Neg stage II discovered summer of 2007. Surgery, Chemo, Radiation. We thought we were in the clear until Jan 2011. Mets to Lungs, bone and liver. Currently taking Halaven Dx 1/31/2011, Stage IV, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Don't know how much time this will put back on the clock but I'll take every second I can get. This news came at a great time since we had to visit the doctor this week for breathing problems an that brought her down. Got her pimped full of decade on and ready to go to daughters college graduation tomorrow. BOOM! Husband of Stage IV BC patient. Triple Neg stage II discovered summer of 2007. Posts.Title: First good scan PizzaDad Leah_S

Posts.Content: PizzaDad wrote: I'm sitting by Elka's bed staring at her monitor. Hoping her heart rate will come down and her bp will go up a little. Yesterday she was running errands and picking the kids up from school. Today she is struggling in the hospital. We had dinner last night and she went to bed afterwards like she often does. I went out to my garage to work on the old car we bought last week. An old grand wagoneer that she has always wanted. Her dream car. Perfect for spring beach at the shore. I came in around 1030 took a shower and we lay in bed talking and watching tv till midnight. When I got up this morning she was slow to respond. Didn't want to be touched. Nauseous. After a couple trips to the bathroom I saw her getting weaker so I was going to take her to the doctor. Ended up calling an ambulance. Here we are. Tachicardia and low pressure all day. Trying to get fluids in her to get her stabilized. Docs are tryin to pinpoint the cause. Scans are scheduled if they can get her stable enough. Her priest came and gave her the sacrament for anointing the ill. My daughter was home ( she came home and went camping nearby for spring break so she could be close) Had my boys brought to the hospital and told them the truth. We are Hopi g that she rides this out as she has some other bad days but they needed to understand that she might be slipping away and they needed to be able to say goodbye. The docs and nurses are great and she is being treated very well. Really there is nothing to do except sit here with her and let her figure out if she is able to fight thru this and stay with us a while longer. Husband of Stage IV BC patient. Triple Neg stage II discovered summer of 2007. Surgery, Chemo, Radiation. We thought we were in the clear until Jan 2011. Mets to Lungs, bone and liver. Currently taking Halaven Dx 1/31/2011, Stage IV, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 10:59PM PizzaDad wrote: When my wife's cancer was discovered it was described as "innumerable tumors"  I have only looked at a scan of it once.  The best way I can describe it is birdshot.  it's hundreds, perhaps of thousands of tiny pinpoint tumors.    From what I have read on here each person's experience is unique and their response to treatment is also unique.  Initial bout with cancer was Summer of 2007.  Recurrence was discovered early January 2011.

Trying to get fluids in her to get her stabilized. Docs are tryin to pinpoint the cause. Scans are scheduled if they can get her stable enough. Her priest came and gave her the sacrament for anointing the ill. My daughter was home ( she came home and went camping nearby for spring break so she could be close) Had my boys brought to the hospital and told them the truth. We are Hopi g that she rides this out as she has some other bad days but they needed to understand that she might be slipping away and they needed to be able to say goodbye. The docs and nurses are great and she is being treated very well. Really there is nothing to do except sit here with her and let her figure out if she is able to fight thru this and stay with us a while longer. Husband of Stage IV BC patient. Triple Neg stage II discovered summer of 2007. Surgery, Chemo, Radiation. We thought we were in the clear until Jan 2011. Mets to Lungs, bone and liver. Currently taking Halaven Dx 1/31/2011, Stage IV, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: In hospital again PizzaDad soleil505

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2012 03:28AM PizzaDad wrote: It was rough last night. I thought she was slipping away from me. Slowly they started getting her pulse down. Then her bp started crashing hard. She is sitting up periodically now. Pain in abdomen but scans don't show anything. No new involvement. Lungs are unchanged except for inflammation. Not out of the woods but so much better. Thank you eryone for the support. She has been able to talk some this morning and is telling me all the stuff I need to know to manage the house. I don't like these conversations but we have pussyfooted around these topic until now. Last night as I held her hand I thought she was dieing and said my goodbyes. This morning she told me she thought she was also and wanted to stop fighting and wasn't sure she could do that again. She is still with me and I'm hoping they can get the rest of her symptoms clear sonwe can have a lote more time.
Posts.Title: In hospital again PizzaDad soleil505

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2012 07:20AM - edited Mar 11, 2012 07:55PM by PizzaDad Elka is being moved to a more "normal" room. She doesn't require the intensive super vision she was re receiving. Hoping to get her home in a day or two.
Posts.Title: In hospital again PizzaDad soleil505

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2012 12:18PM PizzaDad wrote: Doc came by today an said she can go home tomorrow. Such good news. Twice today she was up in a chair watching tv. First time for about 5 hours and even had a couple visitors. I've mostly kept people away. She doesn't know how to go Half throttle... Never has. After being up and out of bed for so long she crashed hard for about 2 hours. So the next time I nagged her after 2 hours. I'll be happy to get her home and get her back to health so we can take that ride to the beach

Posts.Title: Abraxane and chemo brain? PizzaDad steelrose

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 08:44PM PizzaDad wrote: Sido, I am sorry that hit you at such a bad time.  It was fear.  It motivates people do do all sorts of things that they know shouldn't be done.  Even after we had fought thru the first round with cancer I still didn't understand a lot of it.  They try to sell you on the belief of it being gone....and really that is a good thing because if alleviates the fear.  There is no way of knowing if you are going to be one of the unfortunate ones who has the cancer come back but people need to have something to believe in. They need to believe that they are going to be ok.
Posts.Title: People are un-freaking believe-able... Sido PizzaDad

Posts.Content: PizzaDad wrote: So many bad scans. Wife was scanned yesterday. Doctor called to say the cancer got smaller. To us this is a miracle. Don't know how much time this will put back on the clock but I'll take every second I can get. This news came at a great time since we had to visit the doctor this week for breathing problems an that brought her down. Got her pimped full of decade on and ready to go to daughters college graduation tomorrow. BOOM! Husband of Stage IV BC patient. Triple Neg stage II discovered summer of 2007. Posts.Title: First good scan PizzaDad Leah_S

Posts.Content: PizzaDad wrote: Xeloda didn't do everything we needed it to do.  Progression in the lungs, some in the sternum, and a new tumor in the liver.  Taxotere is our new drink.  Start next week.  The doctor didn't seem to hopeful this time.  That really knocked me down. My beautiful wife is still trying to stay at work...I am still trying to get her to take disability.  I've looked all ove the net for some kind of study that looks promising for TN but see nothing.  Things feel very desperate.  We are just trying to put our minds toward the vacation she promised the kids a couple years ago......coming up soon.   Husband of Stage IV BC patient.
